Award.AbstractNarration: This project is to validate and refine the use of incoherent scatter radar (ISR) to measure atmospheric properties of the mesosphere (65-90 km), a key region for energy and momentum transfer between the lower and upper atmosphere. Based on existing data from both the Arecibo Observatory and the AMISR array located in Alaska, as well as new data acquired during the course of this work, this project will improve interpretation of radar backscatter from the collision-dominated mesospheric plasma, a long-standing problem owing to the presence of heavy ions, negative ions, and layer structuring. Specifically, this project is to compare theoretical scattering models with experimental data from the two sites and to compare chemistry models with the derived parameters. Analysis of the resulting mesospheric parameters will be conducted to investigate open questions on mesospheric chemistry and dynamics, particularly regarding the role of minor constituents, as well as climatological dependencies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There are two major objectives for the proposed research: (1) to demonstrate the viability

Of the incoherent scatter technique in the D-region, determine its capabilities and limitations and

(2) To understand the mesospheric aeronomy by studying the diurnal, seasonal, solar and aurora

induced variations in the mesospheric parameters.

TASKS ACCOMPLISHED DURING THE PROJECT::

DATA ACQUISITION/ANALYSIS:

  1. P. I made several visits to Arecibo and collected new data as well as analysis of existing data.  Dr. Nicols at SRI, International has provided assorted data from AMISR radars based on the earlier requirements provided to him. Currently none of the facilities (Arecibo or AMISR) have real time data processing or data pre-processing arrangements in place.  Only the raw data samples are collected during an experiment and there is no efficient way of visualizing the nature of the data being collected. Nevertheless, with the help of Arecibo staff we have been able to read the raw data tapes. Analysis routines have been rewritten for Arecibo and the same routines are being used for AMISR data. A graduate student Eframir Franco, has been hired to work part time on the data analysis at Arecibo. Essentially, both the data acquisition routines and the analysis routines had to be re-developed from scratch. This is now complete and we have at our disposal a set of mesospheric programs which can be used to perform preliminary analysis of any mesospheric data from any facility.
  2. SCATTERING MECHANISM:

AMISR data collected by Nicols et al (personal communication) appear to indicate a significantly large radar cross section for the so called incoherent scatter signal at AMISR. This raises the question whether it is due to a strong hi-latitude mesosphere or due to non-thermal scattering. Similar doubts about the scattering from the EISCAT have been raised by Hansen et al and others.

The Bragg scattering scale sizes are of the order of lambda/2 and based on our understanding of the inertial sub-range for viscous damping, the scattering process should be thermal. Presence of coherent DN/N process is unlikely, but may not be totally ruled out.  A novel experiment has been designed and the data taking and analysis programs have been developed to test these hypotheses.    The experiments were planned, but could not be carried out due to scheduling problems at Arecibo during the last years.

AERONOMY:

Existing D-region data from Arecibo available with the P.I. have been analyzed for a strong solar flare event and for several instances with clear presence of vertically propagating gravity waves.  For the first time evidences of negative ion variations during the solar flare, particularly during the decay phase has been obtained. This qualitatively confirms the effectively large time constant of the negative ion chemistry. Simplified chemistry model for the D region including the negative ions has been developed and is currently being extended for the time dependent analysis. Simulation with the time dependent model will provide quantitative estimates of negative ion reaction rates.

Data with gravity waves have also been searched out and analyzed. The gravity waves manifest themselves in several parameters of the incoherent scatter signals from the mesosphere: vertical velocity, electron density and approximate ratio of Neutral temperature and neutral density are the most prominent indicators. Good quality data have been analyzed for height ranges 65 to 90 Km. and with time resolution of about 1 minute.
